p.s: In the following I'm going to analyze Shakespeare's Sonnet 116.
He wrote it at the end of the 16th century.
It is at the end of his sequenzesequence about the young menman.
He had a relationship to a woman and describes his idea of love.
The sonnet has three quartrainsquatrains and a closing couplet.
So all in all there are 14 verses.
The rhyme scheme is typical for ShakespearShakespeare.
First there are cross rhymes.
In the couplet there is a pair rhyme (abab cdcd efef gg).
The metrum is an iambic pentameter.
In the first quartrainquatrain the personal speaker describes love as not transitory.
He also says that love doesn't change with age (cf. v. 1-4).
The second quartrainquatrain is about the fact that the personal speaker thinks love helps to find the right way in life.
Especially for people who don't know who they are love can give a direction (cf. l. 5-8).
In the third quartrainquatrain the speaker says that love never gets old and exists upon death (cf. v. 9-12).
In the couplet gets clear that there is a paradox.
If love would be like the personal speaker described it before, no one ever loved (cf. v. 13-14).
In the sonnet there are two significant wordfields.
The first is about love.
It contains words like marriage (v. 1), Love (v. 2), love (v. 2) and loved (v. 14).
This shows that the sonnet is about love and the speaker's idea of that.
The next wordfield is about getting older.
Siri you can find words or idioms like alters (v. 3), time's fool (v. 9), rosy lips and cheeks (v. 9), sickle's compass (v. 10) and doom (v. 12).
The speakers so tries to describe the process of love at every time of the life.
He comes to the conclusion that love isn't transitory and also don'tdoesn't change.
In verse one there is the metaphor marriage of true minds.
That should show that the speaker only means true love where both take the relationship very serious.
For him it is really important that between two people who have such a releationshipvrelationship there aren't any problems.
With the contrast Love is not love (v. 2) he makes clear that there are differences between love and love.
It seems like for him only love is that important and special.
If you love someone the feelings can get changed or on that much if you are older but if you love the feelings are constantly there.
The metaphor ever-fixed mark (v. 9) shows on the one hand that the love exists constant until the end of life and on the other hand that love gives you an orientation in life.

The metaphor in verse six shows that love gives you that much orientation that you can solve any problem you have and that there aren't that much problems anymore (tempest and is never shaken, (v. 6)).
With the symbol star (v. 7) he specifies the idea that love gives an orientation.
The polestar for example was something the seafarer used as orientation when they don't have a compass.
The every wandering ship (v. 8) he used as a symbol for the people who couldn't find their love yet and who don't know here they should go ir where they belong to.
They don't even know how amazing they are (v. 9).
But the star is calculating his distance so the people will find their love soon (v. 9).
This metaphor shows that the personal speaker thinks that everyone has someone he could love.
They even find each other so everyone could experience real love.
With a parallelism in verse nine and eleven the speaker shows that love is something good and if sometimes not all works well it is never love's fool.
Also the time (v. 9) never dodoes something false.
Rosy lips and cheeks(v. 9) stand as a symbol for being young.
The sickle's compass (v. 10) is a symbol for being old and experienced your whole life.
This shows that love is a every point of your life.
And even if you experience love as a young adult she will never gone away (cf. v. 11).
Love only can get destroyed due death (v. 11).
This gets clear due the symbol doom which stands for the day of death (v. 12).
The speaker here uses a lot of words from the word field of getting older because he wants to show the process of love.
In addition it gets clear that if you found your love she will never get lost except someone diedies.
In the closing couplet the speaker comes to that conclusion that is idea of love isn't very realistic.
First he says that if this gets approved and his false he never writs, nor no man ever loved (v. 14).
This shows that he is very convinced by himself and is sure that his idea of love is the only correct.
But he also hast to know that his point of view isn't right because not everyone is until his death in a perfect relationship.
Anyway he is sure that only his idea of love is right.
Because of this he comes to the conclusion that either his ideas right or no one ever loved (cf. v. 14).
The personal speaker only uses at the beginning and at the end personal pronouns like me (v. 1) and I (v. 14).
This should show that he means all people and that he is only one part of the others.
With the sonnet the personal speaker tries to convince the reader and wants to show that his idea of love is the best.
All in all the personal speaker has the opinion that everyone will find his real love.
This love exists until someone diedies.
He tries to convince the reader by using a lot of metaphors and symbols.
With the help of word fields his point of view also gets clearer.
